awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Three-Dimensional Unsteady Flow Interactions in Flocks and Schools
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is focused on extending our knowledge of the fluid dynamic interactions that occur in animal collectives, that is, flocks, schools and swarms.  The overarching research goal of the program is to understand the flow mechanisms that occur among unsteady, three-dimensional interacting bodies in complex arrangements.  The educational goal is to promote the engagement of women in STEM by providing engineering experiences for middle school, undergraduate and graduate female students through a schooling twiddle-fish design competition as a part of Lehigh University's CHOICES program.  By examining the three-dimensional, unsteady interactions that occur in collectives, an understanding of the energetics of schooling in nature will be elucidated.  Additionally, the fundamental knowledge to engineer schools of bio-inspired devices will be discovered leading to fast, efficient, maneuverable, agile and quiet collective machines.  Better estimates of the energy budget of schooling animals will lead to more accurate population models.  This will help scientists determine how fragile biological networks are to overfishing, loss of habitat and the changing climate.  Novel control of rotorcraft vortex-blade interactions and of aircraft wings in response to atmospheric vortical gusts may be possible.  New three-dimensional arrangements of wind and hydrokinetic turbines that use synergistic interactions may be discovered.

Advances in flow diagnostics, force sensors and knowledge of unsteady, vortical flows over the past decade have opened the door to characterizing and understanding the fluid mechanics of collective interactions.  The flow physics can be viewed as highly three-dimensional, unsteady, vortex-body interactions with the influence of a vorticity control device, i.e. an oscillating propulsor.  These flows are characterized by high Reynolds numbers, biologically relevant thrust-producing Strouhal numbers, and high reduced frequencies placing them outside of the regime of classical vortex-body interactions.  The specific research objectives are to: (1) characterize the forces, energetics and flow physics of collective locomotion for varying synchrony and various arrangements typical of animals; (2) examine the hypothesis that the lattice-like arrangements seen in nature may be due to fluid-mediated forces; (3) determine how canonical vortical wake topologies of individuals are mapped to energetically-optimal or fluid-mediated collective arrangements; (4) determine scaling laws for the design of schooling bio-inspired vehicles; and (5) detail the flow physics of self-propelled interacting bodies.  The proposed research will be an integration of experiments and computations.  A novel cyber-physical apparatus will be developed to examine the unconstrained dynamics that emerge from self-propelled interacting bodies.  Additionally, novel extensions of our in-house fast boundary element method will be leveraged to explore large numbers of self-propelled interacting bodies. The proposed measurements and numerics will quantify for the first time the three-dimensional fluid-mediated forces between interacting propulsors giving insight into stable equilibria for individuals in a collective.  The detailed stereoscopic flow measurements will capture the mechanisms associated with high performance.  This novel data will settle the debate as to whether animals' lattice-like arrangements are for energetic reasons, are a by-product of fluid-mediated forces, or neither.  From this research, engineers will be able to develop efficient and fast schools of bio-inspired devices.  Knowledge of collective interactions also provides further insight into the dynamics of animals and robots flying and swimming near a free surface, a wall or the ground.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
In this research project we have detailed the basic hydrodynamic interactions that occur among fish in a school. Understanding the hydrodynamics of fish schools allows scientists to better understand the swimming capabilities and energy use of fish when they school, which can lead to better estimates of the fragility of fish populations and could alter fishing quotas to better protect our ecosystems. This is especially important as climate change makes fish populations more likely to experience scarcity in their food sources.  Understanding schooling hydrodynamics also helps engineers who are designing and building the next generation of underwater robots that swim like fish and can take advantage of schooling hydrodynamics to swim better together than in isolation. Schooling interactions can be complicated by the wide variety of fish species that school, which have a wide range of shapes, sizes, and body/fin motions that are used to propel them through water. To simplify our measurements and simulations, we used an idealized model of pitching hydrofoils to represent our fish and probed the basic hydrodynamic interactions of two interacting foils. Our research goals were to: (1) Characterize the forces, energetics and flow physics of collective locomotion for varying synchrony and various arrangements typical of animal locomotion. (2) Examine the hypothesis that the lattice-like arrangements seen in nature may be due to fluid-mediated forces. (3) Determine how canonical vortical wake topologies of isolated individuals are mapped to energetically optimal or fluid-mediated collective arrangements. (4) Determine scaling laws for the engineering design of schooling bio-inspired vehicles. (5) Detail the flow physics of self-propelled interacting bodies.  

Through our research we discovered that many schooling formations can endow the individuals in a school with substantial thrust and/or efficiency benefits.  We discovered the existence flow-mediated equilibrium states between two swimmers where their formation is stable to perturbations due to the cohesive forces that arise from the fluid flow.  A major conclusion that we have found is that indeed these equilibria exist even in two perturbation dimensions and their location depends on the synchrony of motion between the swimmers as well as the kinematic motions of the swimmers.  We have further determined that highly three-dimensional interactions can be crudely modeled with classic unsteady flow theory, and that the highest performance benefits occur when there is direct vortex impingement on a swimmer.  All these results will have a large impact on providing estimates of the energetic benefit of schooling, an understanding of the role of fluid forces in the emergent formations of schools, and an understanding of the flow mechanisms behind these features. By understanding the flow mechanisms that alter the performance of swimmers in a school we are learning more about three-dimensional vortex-body interactions thereby impacting our understanding of blade-vortex interactions in rotorcraft, vortical gust encounters with aircraft, vortex-body interactions in bio-inspired oscillating hydrofoil power generation devices, as well as ground effect interactions for swimmers and flyers. Through the NSF CAREER funds we have also been able to develop a novel dual-axis air bearing experimental apparatus for measuring free-swimming interactions.  This will open the door to future projects on the stability and maneuverability of formations of bio-inspired vehicles as well as conventional underwater vehicles.

On the educational side we have developed a graduate level unsteady flows course and deployed it for three years at Lehigh University.  This has helped increase the formal training for graduate students and prepare them for advanced work in fluid mechanics.  We have also brought this research to the classroom to discuss results that we have found on unsteady ground effect as an example of modern research in fluid mechanics. We have completed the development and deployment of an educational module for Lehigh University's Charting Horizons and Opportunities in Careers in Engineering and Science (CHOICES) program.  During the summer of 2023 there were 20 middle school girls who attended the schooling educational module.  They designed a twiddle fish schooling formation for a competition to find the fastest formation.  This basic design competition exposed the students to the idea that hydrodynamic interactions can change the performance of a fish school and that this relates to their swimming speed and energy use: two important metrics for survival. We further discussed some of the basic findings of our NSF research and acknowledged our NSF funding source.

 


Last Modified: 12/29/2023
Modified by: Keith W Moored
por.por_txt_cntn:

They designed a twiddle fish schooling formation for a competition to find the fastest formation. This basic design competition exposed the students to the idea that hydrodynamic interactions can change the performance of a fish school and that this relates to their swimming speed and energy use: two important metrics for survival. We further discussed some of the basic findings of our NSF research and acknowledged our NSF funding source.
